text: racers at the sliding track in Sochi are
likely to reach 85 miles an hour faster
than highway speeds nearly everywhere
but the track designers wanted to avoid
the 95 mile an hour speeds reached in
Vancouver where George and Luger Nodar
Kumaritashvili was killed during a
training run so the profile of this
course in the mountains above Sochi
includes three uphill sections which
will pose challenges of their own
the first uphill stretch occurs near the
end of curve five and slows the sled by
about eight miles an hour but here at
the sweeping u-turn a curve ten the
racers will find their toughest
challenge there are three waves in the
driving line of this turn and its
fastest to steer at these moments
missing them even slightly will send
racers on a longer path costing them
precious time drivers are used to
exiting a curve going downhill but here
the track rises making it more difficult
to find a straight and fast line into
the next section
the largest uphill section is the
entrance to curve 15 where the track
hops over itself like a highway overpass
here the sharp change in elevation means
the athletes cannot see the exit of the
curve making their memorization of the
track even more crucial like the other
parts of the course that go uphill this
one may separate medalists from the rest
